info.game_comments:
1997 International Tournament final game 1.
From Stockholm, Sweden.

(1, 1).clue: According to tradition, Zeus' home was on this mountain on the Thessaly/Macedonia border

(2, 1).clue: The name of this religion of Haiti is derived from a Dahomean word for "spirit"

(3, 1).clue: D'Artagnan is the swashbuckling hero of this author's "The Three Musketeers"

(4, 1).clue: The device for doing this to flour is basically a cup with a mesh screen

(5, 1).clue: It's "clear" he's the perfect choice to host the Oscars; since 1990, he's done it 5 times

(1, 2).clue: One account had her opening a jar, not a box, but she still shuts it before hope escapes

(2, 2).clue: Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, lies on this "Beautiful Blue" river

(3, 2).clue: He's scared readers with such popular novels as "It", "Carrie" & "The Stand"

(4, 2).clue: The soup of these split vegetables is popular in the Middle East as well as in colder areas

(5, 2).clue: This superstar & Cuba Gooding, Jr. were both nominated for "Jerry Maguire"; Cuba won

(1, 3).clue: Asterius was the real name of this bull-headed creature

(2, 3).clue: The concept of Tapu---sacredness---is sacred to these indigenous people of New Zealand

(3, 3).clue: This British author wrote "The War in the Air" as well as "The War of the Worlds"

(4, 3).clue: If you don't want to break this dish used to make aspic or pudding, use one of metal, not ceramic

(5, 3).clue: Best actress Frances McDormand played a pregnant cop in this film named for a North Dakota city

(1, 4).clue: After Zeus mated with Leda, disguised as this bird, Castor & Pollux were born in an egg

(2, 4).clue: It's the seductive ballroom dance most associated with Buenos Aires

(3, 4).clue: He died in 1924 without completing "The Trial" & "The Castle"

(4, 4).clue: The name of these tiny dumplings served as a side dish means "little sparrow" in German

(5, 4).clue: This Frenchwoman was surprised to win for "The English Patient"; she thought Lauren Bacall deserved it

(1, 5).clue: She & Athena had a weaving contest

(2, 5).clue: Kiunguja, which is spoken in Zanzibar, is a dialect of this African Bantu language

(3, 5).clue: 1943's "Magister Ludi", or "The Glass Bead Game", was the last novel by this German author

(4, 5).clue: The name of this consomme flavored with tomato juice comes from "Madrid"

(5, 5).clue: This pianist made a surprise appearance on the show, & Geoffrey Rush won for playing him in "Shine"

(1, 1).clue: Opera composer Renzo Rossellini was the brother of this film director

(2, 1).clue: It's the smaller of the 2 countries on the Iberian Peninsula

(3, 1).clue: Astronomers divide the sky into 88 of these star groups

(4, 1).clue: "Slow and steady wins the race" is a well-known moral from one of his fables

(5, 1).clue: Through his writings, this Venetian gives us a description of Kublai Khan & his palace at Shang-Tu

(6, 1).clue: The Pied Piper led these 2 groups out of Hamelin

(1, 2).clue: This beautiful figure skater was once called "The Brooke Shields of East Germany"

(2, 2).clue: Prince Albert I founded this tiny principality's Musee Oceanographique in 1910

(3, 2).clue: In 1705 he announced that the comets of 1531, 1607, & 1682 were the same comet

(4, 2).clue: He wrote, "My name is Sherlock Holmes, it is my business to know what other people don't know"

(5, 2).clue: While scaling Mount Everest in April 1953, Tenzing Norgay rescued this man who had fallen into a crevasse

(6, 2).clue: In 1910 Georges Claude created these lights, now popular in Las Vegas & Piccadilly Circus

(2, 3).clue: This small country in the Pyrenees uses the money of its neighbors, France & Spain

(3, 3).clue: At about 600 miles in diameter, Ceres is the largest first discovered of these minor planets

(4, 3).clue: This ancient Chinese philosopher said, "When you have faults, do not fear to abandon them"

(5, 3).clue: In 1769 he & the crew of the Endeavour built Fort Venus on Matavai Bay in Tahiti

(6, 3).clue: The Holland type of this liquor first made in Holland is usually drunk straight

(1, 4).clue: Once a star of the Kirov Ballet, this man, nicknamed Misha, now tours with the White Oak Dance Project

(2, 4).clue: This country's supreme court is in Sucre, not in La Paz

(3, 4).clue: A galactic cloud of dust & gas, its name comes from the Latin for "cloud"

(4, 4).clue: Among his last words at the battle of Trafalgar were "Thank God, I have done my duty"

(5, 4).clue: The Gjoa, this 20th C. Norwegian's ship, was exhibited in San Francisco 1906-1972, when it was returned to Oslo

(6, 4).clue: In 1930 he officially changed the name of Constantinople to Istanbul

(1, 5).clue: Some of this U.S. pop artist's silkscreens are in a museum in Slovakia, near his parents' birthplace

(2, 5).clue: Founded as an Egyptian army camp in the 1820s, Khartoum is now the capital of this country

(3, 5).clue: In the "Almagest", this 2nd century Greek astronomer suggested the Earth was the center of the universe

(4, 5).clue: In "The Social Contract" he wrote, "Man was born free and he is everywhere in chains"

(5, 5).clue: In 1642 this Dutchman was commissioned to find the Great Southern Continent

(6, 5).clue: This northern Tanzania national park is twice the size of Yellowstone

(0, 0).clue: Princess Sophia of Greece gave up her right of succession to Greece's throne before marrying him in 1962
